'''''Portmar''''' was a United States-flagged merchant vessel that was constructed in response to World War I, operated by a succession of companies in the interwar period, then taken up for wartime shipping in World War II. The ship was built to [[Design 1013 ship|Design 1013]], as part of wartime orders by the [[United States Shipping Board]] (USSB). She was laid down by [[Northwest Steel]] of [[Portland, Oregon]], with the name '''''West Minsi'''''. The USSB order was cancelled during construction, but Northwest Steel completed the ship for private sale. She was sold to the [[Green Star Line]] before launching in November 1919, and was assigned the name '''''Centaurus'''''. The freighter was sold to Nafra in 1920, then on to the [[Planet Steamship Company]] in 1923. In 1929, the ship was sold to the [[Calmar Steamship Company]], who renamed the ship ''Portmar''. In late 1941, ''Portmar'' was chartered by the [[United States Department of War]] to carry supplies to the Philippines but due to the [[Philippines Campaign (1941–42)|Japanese invasion of the Philippines]] was retained in Australia. She was used in February 1942 to carry reinforcements from Darwin for the [[Sparrow Force|defenders of Timor]] prior to the [[Battle of Timor|Japanese invasion]]. The reinforcement convoy was shadowed by Japanese planes and attacked, forcing its cancellation. ''Portmar'' returned to Darwin on 18 February, and was still in harbour the next day when Japanese carrier-based aircraft [[Bombing of Darwin|attacked the city]] in the first ever attack on Australia. The ship was heavily damaged, and run aground to prevent sinking. ''Portmar'' was later refloated, towed to Sydney, repaired, purchased by the United States Army and put back into service as an Army transport. In June 1943, she sailed as part of [[convoy GP55]]. On 15 June, off [[Smoky Cape]], ''Portmar'' and the landing ship [[USS LST-469|''LST-469'']] were torpedoed by the Japanese submarine [[Japanese submarine I-174|''I-174'']]. Due to a highly volatile cargo, ''Portmar'' was abandoned and sank in less than ten minutes. She was the last ship lost to the [[Axis naval activity in Australian waters|Japanese submarine campaign in Australian waters]]. == Design and construction == {{Main article|Design 1013 ship}} The ship was built to [[Design 1013 ship|Design 1013]] or the "''Robert Dollar'' type", a standardised freighter design ordered by the [[United States Shipping Board]] (USSB) from multiple west-coast shipyards during World War I.McKeller, ''Steel Shipbuilding under the U. S. Shipping Board, 1917–1921: Contract Steel Ships, Part I'', p. 475a Standard dimensions were {{convert|410.5|ft}} in length, with a beam of {{convert|54|ft}} and a standard draft of {{convert|30|ft}}. This vessel varied a little from the standard, being {{convert|409.8|ft|m|2}} long and {{convert|54.2|ft|m|2}} beam. Depth was {{convert|27.7|ft|m|2}} with a draft of {{convert|30.2|ft|m|2}}.{{cite web |url=http://www.plimsollshipdata.org/pdffile.php?name=30b0953.pdf |title=Lloyd's Register, Steamers & Motorships |author=Lloyd's of London |year=1930 |publisher=Plimsoll Ship Data |accessdate=24 June 2015}} They had a [[deadweight tonnage]] value of 8,800, and a [[gross register tonnage]] of 5,551. Her [[net register tonnage]] was 3,418. Propulsion machinery varied across the type: this ship used oil-fuelled boilers, connected to triple-expansion steam engines.{{cite web |url=http://www.plimsollshipdata.org/pdffile.php?name=30b0953.pdf |title=Lloyd's Register, Steamers & Motorships |publisher=Plimsoll Ship Data |accessdate=24 June 2015}} The engine was built by the [[Hooven-Owens-Rentschler|Hooven, Owens & Rentschler Company]] of [[Hamilton, Ohio]]. It had cylinders of {{convert|24.5|in|cm}}, {{convert|41.5|in|cm}} and {{convert|68|in|cm}} diameter by {{convert|48|in|cm}} stroke. It was rated at 582 [[nominal horsepower|NHP]]. One hundred and five vessels were completed for the USSB, while this ship and four others were cancelled but completed and sold privately by the shipyards, and others cancelled outright. The ship was laid down by [[Northwest Steel]] of [[Portland, Oregon]] as yard number 38 and USSB number 2373, with the name ''West Minsi''.McKeller, ''Steel Shipbuilding under the U. S. Shipping Board, 1917–1921: Contract Steel Ships, Part I'', pp. 477–8{{cite web |url=http://www.shipbuildinghistory.com/history/shipyards/4emergencylarge/wwone/northweststeel.htm |title=Northwest Steel, Portland OR |date=27 November 2010 |work=Shipbuilding History |accessdate=24 June 2015}} During construction, the order for this ship was cancelled by the USSB [[United States Shipping Board Merchant Fleet Corporation|Emergency Fleet Corporation]], but construction continued for private sale.McKeller, ''Steel Shipbuilding under the U. S. Shipping Board, 1917–1921: Contract Steel Ships, Part I'', p. 478 By the time the ship was launched on 17 November 1919, she had been sold to the [[Green Star Line]] and assigned the name ''Centaurus''.{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2676882/the_oregon_daily_journal/ |title=Hull No. 38 Is Launched |date=17 November 1919 |pages=12 |accessdate=25 June 2015}} The ship was completed in December 1919, and assigned the United States [[official number]] 219283 and [[Code Letters]] LTVH. == Operational history == The first voyage of ''Centaurus'' departed from [[Astoria, Oregon]] in late December 1919, bound for [[Callao]], Peru.{{cite news |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2676874/the_oregon_daily_journal/ |title=Astoria Boy Dies; Cruelty Charged |date=22 October 1920 |work=The Oregon Daily Journal |pages=8 |accessdate=25 June 2015}} During the voyage, one of the crewmen suffered a mental breakdown over concerns about his invalid passport. Instead of providing medical assistance, the sailor was [[Leg irons|placed in irons]], removed from the crew list and relisted as a [[stowaway]], then abandoned on the dockside when ''Centaurus'' departed Callao on 17 January 1920. The crewman ended up in an insane asylum, where he died later that year. * 18 January 1920. The newspaper "[[The Sunday Oregonian]]", [[Portland, Oregon|Portland]], wrote on the page 46: '''GREEN STAR WILL PLY ATLANTIC'''
'''Four Steamers Purchased Here to Sail From Baltimore.'''
'''ORIENTAL RUN PROMISED'''
'''Cruft Now Being Built at Standifer Plant Expected to Be Operated on Pacific.'''
Speculation as to the future field of operations of the Green Star Steamship company, which purchased four steel steamers in [[Portland, Oregon|Portland]] and placed orders for the construction of five more, was ended last week by a formal announcement from the headquarters of the company in [[Baltimore]], where the Green Star line has pur chased a large building to serve as a home for its shipping enterprises. The last of the steamers purchased by, the line here, the ''Circlnus'', sailed from [[Astoria, Oregon|Astoria]] Wednesday with a full cargo of lumber for [[Melbourne]] and [[Adelaide]], Australia. This cargo amounted to 4.086,103 feet, it is reported by Brown & McCabe, stevedores, who had charge of loading the vessel.
The three other steamers purchased here by the Green Star line are the ''Corvus'', which went in ballast to [[Arica]], Chile, to load nitrates for [[Europe]]; the '''''Centaurus''''', which took a part cargo of lumber here and went to [[San Francisco]] to finish a general cargo for the west coast, and the ''Clauseus'', which went from here to San Francisco in ballast to load beans for [[Hamburg]].[http://oregonnews.uoregon.edu/lccn/sn83045782/1920-01-18/ed-1/seq-46/ocr.txt The Sunday "OREGOXIAX, PORTLAND," JANUARY 18, 1920. >> GREEN STAR WILL PLYS ATLANTIC][http://oregonnews.uoregon.edu/lccn/sn83045782/1920-01-18/ed-1/seq-46/ Historic Oregan Nespaper >> The Sunday Oregonian. (Portland, Ore.) 1881-current, January 18, 1920, SECTION TWO, Image 46] Later in 1920, ''Centaurus'' was sold to Nafra Company which was affiliated with Green Star having intertwined financial affairs in ship acquisition.{{cite book |last=United States Congress, House, Select committee on U. S. Shipping Board Operations |year=1920 |title=Shipping board operations |series= |volume=8 |location=Washington |publisher=U.S. Government Printing Office |page=3331 |url=https://archive.org/stream/shippingboardop02housgoog#page/n175/mode/1up |accessdate=26 June 2015}} She operated for this company until 1923, when she was sold to the [[Planet Steamship Company]]. In December 1929, ''Centaurus'' and four other Planet freighters (''Circinius'', ''Corvus'', ''Clauseus'', and ''Eurana'') were sold to the [[Calmar Steamship Company]].{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2676921/oakland_tribune/ |title=Calmar Buys Ships |date=13 December 1929 |work=Oakland Tribune |page=61 |accessdate=25 June 2015}} * 13 of December 1929. The newspaper "Oakland Tribune" in Oakland, California, wrote: [[File:Isthmian Lines House Flag.jpg|thumb|270px|[[Isthmian Lines]] House Flag from 1910 to 1974.]] "CALMAR BUYS SHIPS.
The "Calmar Line" has purchased five freighters from the "Planet Steamship company", according to announcement from New York. This purchase increases the Calmar intercoastal fleet to eleven ships. The new craft are 880 tons register.
The vessels involved are all well known on this coast, consisting of the [[SS Circinus|''Circinius'']], ''Corvus'', ''Clauseus'', [[SS Centaurus|''Centaurus'']] and ''Eurana''. They have run into local ports for several years under the [[Isthmian Line]] houseflag".{{cite web|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/?spot=2676921&fcfToken=42783535372f5663642b37662f70364a6279357242763672696a6547766e716539556f434f524d3478675257516c2f4d336b783843625647672b53305252356c |title=Calmar Buys Ships. |publisher=The newspaper "Oakland Tribune" in Oakland, California |date=1929-12-13 |pages=61}} ''Centaurus'' was renamed ''Portmar'', and her port of registry was changed to [[New York City|New York]]. In 1934, her Code Letters were changed to KOPZ.{{cite web |url=http://www.plimsollshipdata.org/pdffile.php?name=34b0677.pdf |title=Lloyd's Register, Navires a Vapeur et a Moteurs |author=Lloyd's of London |year=1934 |publisher=Plimsoll Ship Data |accessdate=24 June 2015}} On 13 July 1937, while on a voyage from [[Boston, Massachusetts]] to [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]], ''Portmar'' collided with the ''Handkerchief Lightvessel'' in dense fog. Although she was undamaged, the [[lightvessel]] was severely damaged.{{Cite newspaper The Times |articlename=Casualty Reports from Lloyd's |day_of_week=Thursday |date=15 July 1937 |page_number=25 |issue=47737 |column=E }} === World War II === On 18 November 1941, ''Portmar'' and seven other ships ({{SS|Iowan||2}}, {{SS|Mauna Loa||2}}, {{SS|West Camargo|1920|2}}, ''{{SS|Steel Voyager||2}}'', {{SS|Jane Christenson|1918|2}}, {{SS|F. J. Luckenbach|1917|2}}, and {{SS|Malama|1919|2}}) were [[ship chartering|chartered]] by the [[United States Department of War]] to carry military supplies to the Philippines.{{cite DANFS |author=Naval Historical Center |title=West Conob |url=http://www.history.navy.mil/research/histories/ship-histories/danfs/w/west-conob.html |archiveurl=http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20140705203716/http%3A//www%2Ehistory%2Enavy%2Emil/danfs/w5/west_conob%2Ehtm |archivedate= July 5, 2014 |accessdate=23 June 2015}}{{cite news |last=Cave |first=Wayne B. |title=New group of freighters drafted for war service |work=Los Angeles Times |date=20 November 1941 |page=33}} The ship was effectively delivered to the United States government on 20 November 1941 in what was a precursor of the delivery of all ocean merchant shipping to the [[War Shipping Administration]] with allocation to the Army.{{cite web |url=http://www.marad.dot.gov/sh/ShipHistory/Detail/12109 |title=''Portmar'' |author=Maritime Administration |date= |work=Ship History Database Vessel Status Card |publisher=U.S. Department of Transportation, Maritime Administration |accessdate=24 June 2015}} Even though details of the charters were deemed confidential, the names of all eight ships were published in the ''Los Angeles Times'' two days later. The Japanese invasion of the Philippines resulted in retention in Australia. ''Portmar'' had arrived in Australia as one of the ships carrying fuel and vehicles after the earlier arrival of the diverted [[Pensacola Convoy|Pensacola convoy]].Gill, ''Royal Australian Navy, 1939–1942'', p. 515 ''Portmar'' had departed San Francisco 26 November 1941 sailing independently with 319 vehicles, 5,939 barrels of gasoline, ammunition, bombs, machine guns and other stores for the units sailing in the Pensacola convoy but was diverted while south of Hawaii, first to [[Suva]] then to Sydney with arrival there 31 December 1941.{{cite book |title=Racing the Sunrise—Reinforcing America's Pacific Outposts 1941–1942 |last=Williford |first=Glen M.|authorlink= |coauthors= |year=2010 |publisher=Naval Institute Press |location=Annapolis, Maryland |isbn=978-1-59114-956-9 |lccn=2010030455 |page= |pages= |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7NNHuSNSx0UC&lpg=PA1&pg=PT142#v=onepage&q&f=false |accessdate=25 June 2015}} The ship was one of those initially chosen to attempt to run the Japanese blockade of the Philippines but the rapid Japanese advance and occupation of Rabaul, Kavieng and other strategic points to the north resulted in the ship being recalled to Darwin.{{cite journal |last1=Gibson |first1=Charles Dana |last2=Gibson |first2=E. Kay |year=2008 |title=Attempts to Supply The Philippines by Sea: 1942 |journal=''The Northern Mariner''/''Le marin du nord'' |volume=18 |issue= |page= |location=Ottawa, Ontario |publisher=Canadian Nautical Research Society/Société canadienne pour la recherche nautique |doi= |url=http://www.cnrs-scrn.org/northern_mariner/vol18/tnm_18_3-4_163-172.pdf |accessdate=25 June 2015}} The Maritime Commission was expecting ''Portmar'' along with other large vessels to be returned to the United States but the desperate need for shipping in theater had made local retention necessary.{{cite book |last=Masterson |first=Dr. James R. |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=U. S. Army Transportation In The Southwest Pacific Area 1941–1947 |year=1949 |publisher=Transportation Unit, Historical Division, Special Staff, U. S. Army |location=Washington, D. C. |isbn= |pages=320, 338 |url=http://cgsc.cdmhost.com/cdm/compoundobject/collection/p4013coll11/id/903 |accessdate=24 June 2015}} Before 02:00 on 15 February 1942, ''Portmar'' sailed from Darwin as part of a convoy carrying reinforcements for [[Sparrow Force|the defenders of Timor]].Gill, ''Royal Australian Navy, 1939–1942'', pp. 581, 585 Also in the convoy were the transports {{USAT|Meigs}}, {{SS|Mauna Loa||2}}, and {{MV|Tulagi||2}}, with an escort made up of the [[cruiser]] {{USS|Houston|CA-30|6}}, the [[destroyer]] {{USS|Peary|DD-226|6}}, and the [[sloop of war|sloops]] {{HMAS|Warrego|U73|6}} and {{HMAS|Swan|U74|6}}.Gill, ''Royal Australian Navy, 1939–1942'', p. 581 ''Portmar'', along with ''Tulagi'', carried elements of the U.S. Army [[148th Field Artillery Regiment|148th Field Artillery]] while the other ships had Australian forces embarked.{{cite book |last=Office Of Naval Intelligence |year=1943 |title=The Java Sea Campaign |series=Combat Narratives |location=Washington |publisher=United States Navy |page=36 |url=http://www.history.navy.mil/research/library/online-reading-room/title-list-alphabetically/j/java-sea-campaign.html |accessdate=25 June 2015}} By 11:00, the ships had been spotted by a Japanese flying boat, which followed them for several hours before dropping bombs at around 14:00 with minimal effect.Gill, ''Royal Australian Navy, 1939–1942'', p. 585 The next day, another flying boat began shadowing the convoy around 09:15, and the ships were attacked by a force of 45 Japanese aircraft two hours later. Light damage and some casualties were suffered aboard ''Manua Loa'', while ''Portmar'' was not damaged during the hour-long attack. The likelihood of further attacks and the believed imminent [[Battle of Timor|invasion of Timor]] resulted in orders to turn the convoy around received at 15:15, with all ships back at Darwin by midday on 18 February. [[File:Portmar beached Darwin.png|thumb|220px|right|''Portmar'' beached after attack on Darwin.]] ''Portmar'' was still in Darwin Harbour the next day when a force of Japanese carrier-based aircraft [[Bombing of Darwin|attacked the city]]: the first time Australia had been attacked.Gill, ''Royal Australian Navy, 1939–1942'', pp. 590–1 She was heavily damaged during the attack, and was towed away from her mooring and run aground to prevent her from sinking.Grose, ''An Awkward Truth'', p. 111 One of the crew was killed, and several wounded were later recovered by the examination vessel {{HMAS|Southern Cross}}.Gill, ''Royal Australian Navy, 1939–1942'', p. 593 ''Portmar'' was salvaged and reconditioned by U.S. Army port-battalion troops, towed to Sydney, and repaired.Gill, ''Royal Australian Navy, 1942–1945'', p. 261 The ship was purchased at Brisbane by the War Department on 17 November 1942 and incorporated into the U.S. Army's permanent local fleet as an Army transport. On the morning of 15 June 1943, USAT ''Portmar'', loaded with ammunition and fuel, left Sydney for Brisbane as part of [[convoy GP55]].{{cite web |url=https://www.awm.gov.au/journal/j34/stevens.asp |title=The naval campaigns for New Guinea |last=Stevens |first=David |date= |work=Journal of the Australian War Memorial |publisher=Australian War Memorial |accessdate=25 June 2015 }} The convoy consisted of ten merchant ships (including ''Portmar'') and three [[Landing Ship Tank]] vessels, escorted by the [[Bathurst-class corvette|''Bathurst''-class]] corvettes {{HMAS|Bundaberg|J231|6}}, {{HMAS|Cootamundra||6}}, {{HMAS|Deloraine||6}}, {{HMAS|Kalgoorlie||6}}, and {{HMAS|Warrnambool|J202|6}}. ''Portmar'' was the middle of three ships in the fourth column. ''Portmar'' had trouble maintaining position during the voyage, and at 17:15 on 16 June, when the convoy was {{convert|35|nmi}} east of [[Smoky Cape]], was passing to port of [[USS LST-469|USS ''LST-469'']] to regain convoy position. At this time, the Japanese submarine [[Japanese submarine I-174|''I-174'']] fired a spread of [[torpedo]]es at the convoy from the convoy's starboard: one torpedo struck USS ''LST-469'', and another hit ''Portmar'' almost immediately after. The volatile cargo was ignited, and the order was given to abandon ship. ''Portmar'' sank ten minutes later, with two crewmen killed. The 71 survivors were recovered by HMAS ''Deloraine'', which then took USS ''LST-469'' (which had survived the attack, but was immobilised and had suffered heavy casualties) in tow, and headed for [[Coffs Harbour]]. ''Warnambool'' and ''Kalgoorlie'' depth-charged the area until contact was lost: they were unable to damage ''I-174'', nor were subsequent searches able to locate her. The attack on convoy GP55 was the last [[Axis naval activity in Australian waters|Japanese submarine attack in Australian waters]].Gill, ''Royal Australian Navy, 1942–1945'', p. 262 The loss of shipping, particularly the LST that was part of MacArthur's Seventh Amphibious Force, forced removal of troops and supplies for the occupation of [[Kiriwina]] and [[Woodlark Island]], the first offensive amphibious operations. == Citations == {{reflist|30em}} == References == '''Books''' *{{cite book|last=Gill |first=George Hermon |title=Royal Australian Navy, 1939–1942 |year=1957 |url=http://www.awm.gov.au/histories/second_world_war/volume.asp?levelID=67910 |format=PDF |accessdate=2009-10-12 |series=[[Australia in the War of 1939–1945]], Series 2, Volume I |publisher=Australian War Memorial |location=Canberra |id= |oclc=848228}} *{{cite book|last=Gill |first=George Hermon |title=Royal Australian Navy, 1942–1945 |year=1968 |url=http://www.awm.gov.au/histories/second_world_war/volume.asp?levelID=67911 |format=PDF |accessdate=2009-10-12|series=[[Australia in the War of 1939–1945]], Series 2, Volume II |publisher=Australian War Memorial |location=Canberra |id=[[National Library of Australia|NLA]] registry number Aus 68-1798 |oclc=65475}} *{{cite book|last=Grose |first=Peter |title=An Awkward Truth: The Bombing of Darwin, February 1942 |publisher=Allen & Unwin |location=Crows Nest, NSW |date=2009 |isbn=978-1-74175-643-2 |oclc=271861660 }} '''Journal articles''' *{{cite journal |last1=McKeller |first1=Norman L. |date=September–October 1962 |title=Steel Shipbuilding under the U.
